text.tspan: It was a dark and stormy afternoon in 1752. While the weath
er above the city of Philadelphia told its citizens to go home,
safe from the approaching thunderstorm, a man called
Benjamin Franklin saw the opportunity he had been waiting for.
He took his kite, and with the help of his own son, wanted to
prove that there is a connection between lighting and
The kite consisted of a wire that was meant to behave as a
lightning rod and two strings - one made out of hemp, one
from silk. Hemp was meant to conduct the electrical charge,
whereas the silk string didn’t and therefore it was safe for
Benjamin to hold. To the hemp string, he attached a metal key.
And then he felt it - the threads of the hemp string started to
lift. As he moved his fingers closer to the key, he felt it – a
spark that proved his assumptions right. There was a connec
